node.statement: Prove falling-factorial-sum identity: For j >= 0, sum_{k>=0} k^{underline{j}}/k! = sum_{k>=j} k^{underline{j}}/k! (terms with k<j are 0 by definition of falling-factorial, since k^{underline{j}} = k(k-1)...(k-j+1) contains a factor of 0 when k < j). For k>=j, k^{underline{j}}/k! = k!/(k-j)!/k! = 1/(k-j)!. Index substitution m = k-j is valid since it is a bijection from {k : k >= j} to {m : m >= 0}: the sum sum_{k>=j} 1/(k-j)! = sum_{m>=0} 1/m!. By external reference exp-series with x=1, sum_{m>=0} x^m/m! = e^x converges absolutely for all x (ratio test: |a_{m+1}/a_m| = 1/(m+1) -> 0). Setting x=1: sum_{m>=0} 1/m! = e. The original series inherits absolute convergence via the bijection, hence sum_{k>=0} k^{underline{j}}/k! = e for all j >= 0.
